This speaker can withstand submersion in water up to a depth of 7 feet (IPX7), so you can take it to the beach or the pool without fear of ruining your music. Whereas Marshall Emberton is stylish and contains the essentials, it falls short in a few critical areas. It has a built-in microphone for taking calls but doesn't work with voice assistants. This ought to be anticipated from a portable speaker, but the microphone is a nice addition.


Furthermore, unlike many other Bluetooth speakers, there is no app support for adjusting the equalization. content_list.content:
The black brick-shaped Emberton has a gray metallic mesh grille and the classic white script Marshall emblem on its front face. Dimensionally, it's very little, measuring 2.7 x 6.3 cm x 3.0 inches (HWD), yet it weighs a hefty 1.5 pounds. Although Marshall has updated the speaker, it still has the classic design of earlier generations. The center control panel has a brass finish, which nods to the past, and a red digital LED display on that top panel indicates the battery's charge level, which is quite contemporary. The speaker has Bluetooth 5.0 connectivity and a class-D amplifier powering twin 10-watt drivers.


The Emberton has a great IPX7 certification, which means it is entirely waterproof and can be submerged approximately to a meter (albeit Bluetooth signal doesn't perform well underwater). However, the USB-C connector on the right panel is not protected. The rain, the pool, and the kitchen sink shouldn't bother the speaker in the least. A sensitive four-way rocker in the middle of the device controls the volume, skips tracks, and plays/pause the currently playing track. Shorter pushes manage playback, whereas longer presses turn the speaker on or off. The Bluetooth pairing button is located to the left of the main control. The bottom is rubber-lined to prevent the speaker from sliding around on hard surfaces. A speakerphone feature is notably absent, given the size. There is no auxiliary input jack on the Emberton, and the USB port may only be used to charge the device.
content_list.subtitle: Design

content_list.content:
Even at modest levels, the Emberton produces some surprisingly rich bass considering its size on tunes with heavy sub-bass content, such as "Silent Shout" by The Knife. At maximum intensity, the DSP machine learning kicks in, and although the speaker still pumps out many sounds, the bass impacts become notably less impactful. The trade-off for Emberton's mobility is a lack of bass oomph at maximum levels, which is anticipated given the size. By comparing it to "Drover" by Bill Callahan, a tune with far less sub-bass inside this mix, we may get a clearer idea of the overall sound design. At high settings, the drums on this track may sound thundering with bass-forward speakers, but somehow the Emberton renders them rich and natural over moderate volumes.


Callahan's rich baritone, however, is given enough of limited presence and perhaps some sharp treble edge at all levels. The acoustic strums are likewise rendered with dazzling clarity. This is not a consistent sound signature and varies significantly with loudness, making it unsuitable for purists. However, the Emberton sounds clean and well-balanced throughout the volume range. We discovered the sweet spot for loudness and bass response just a few notches below optimum.The producers of Jay-Z and Kanye West's "No Chapel in the Wild" gave the kick drum loop much more high-mid presence to keep its punchiness, and we can also hear the vinyl hiss and crackle that are typically relegated to the background in a somewhat amplified form.


The Emberton has trouble producing the sub-bass synth hits; they don't distort, although they're not very powerful, even at moderate volumes. However, at maximum power, the drum loop gains some bottom depth, and as before, things become sparse. The vocals on this recording are clear and undistorted, making them easy to understand. At high levels, orchestral music sounds excellent, like the prologue to John Adams' The Apocalypse According to a Different Mary. Lower-register instrumentation sounds full and rich, including its anchoring role, unaffected by the DSP, while relatively high brass, strings, and vocals retain their crispness and clarity. When the volume is dialed back, the bass takes center stage without becoming too dominant.
content_list.subtitle: Performance

content_list.content:
Due to Emberton's striking visual continuity throughout generations, distinguishing between them might be challenging. A closer inspection of the Emberton II reveals several improvements that are not immediately apparent. The two speakers seem virtually similar, except the second one has a pebbled appearance on the outside. Moreover, its longevity is increased. Marshall upgraded from an IPX7 certification, which provides no dust protection, to an IP67 classification, which protects against dust and sand. Many people who like going to the beach will be quite happy. Marshall's internal Bluetooth version is now 5.1 rather than 5.0, and the battery life has been extended to 30 hours. The original Emberton lasted only 20 hours, but the new model increased it by a whopping 50 percent. Unfortunately, the most exciting new feature is also the one that most people won't ever use.


Stack mode enables a gigantic wall of speakers to be created by stacking numerous Emberton II speakers on top of one another. Multiple speakers may be stacked together to provide a more spectacular overall sound. However, this is of little use if you have one speaker and instead makes us think of rows and rows of vintage Marshall amps along the stage's perimeter. One plausible scenario is if you and your buddies agree to listen to the same speaker ahead of time so you can coordinate your efforts when you all get together.
content_list.subtitle: Compared To The Second Generation

content_list.content:
When you turn up on that Marshall Emberton II, you can immediately tell you're using a genuine Marshall product. We like the rough, almost rock-like quality of it. This doesn't mean that just rock or guitar-heavy music will sound well on this speaker. Everything sounded great. However, it wasn't much better than the first generation. We've tried several speakers in this price range, and none of them come close to matching the warmth and expansive soundstage of this one. When used inside, the speaker's maximum volume is too high to be comfortable unless the room is enormous. Our music has a satisfying rumble when played through the Emberton II, which produces a reasonable amount of bass. Thanks to testing other speakers beyond Marshall's limit, we haven't encountered any problems playing music at lower frequencies (below 60Hz). Those that produce greater bass in a compact form risk sounding muddy or overwhelming.

content_list.subtitle: Sound Performance

content_list.content: You may access hidden features by downloading your free Marshall Opportunity for people and connecting your phone to the speaker through Bluetooth. When there are available firmware upgrades, the app may assist you in installing them on your speaker. The app's main function is to fine-tune the speaker using one of three predefined equalization curves. There is no option for a manual EQ control. Either a Marshall or Push system or a voice system may be selected. By a wide margin, our favorite sound from this brand was the Marshall. The use of voice is particularly effective in audiobooks, podcasts, and other works that include extensive conversation. By boosting the highs and lows, the music becomes more forceful and hefty when using the "Push" button. While the bass was somewhat enhanced, our testing showed that Push significantly narrowed the stereo field and muddied the midrange. The trade-off was not worth it since Push sounded worse overall.
content_list.subtitle: App For Marshall Connect

content_list.content: Marshall Emberton stands out because of its design, reminiscent of guitar amplifiers. In the middle of the 'amp's' top panel is a gold, four-way 'joystick' that serves as its primary control mechanism. The device may turn on and off as a volume knob and track skip button. A subtle Bluetooth connectivity button and a red light that glows to show battery life are other notable features that refer to classic amp pilot lights. The lack of complexity is Marshall Emberton's biggest drawback. Without a 3.5mm audio jack and the ability to use a voice assistant, this device falls short in many respects. The fact that it can be charged quickly and has a long battery life (20 hours) makes it convenient to carry on the go, but otherwise, this is a basic Bluetooth speaker.
content_list.subtitle: What You Obtain

content_list.content:
The setup process is as simple as it gets. You may get started with Marshall Emberton immediately after pairing it with a device via Bluetooth. You can't adjust the equalization because of the lack of a companion app, but at least setting it up is quick and easy. The Emberton packs a punch for its compact size thanks to its two 10-watt speakers and dual class-D amplifiers. Its soundstage isn't nearly as broad as advertised, but it's still fairly listenable at moderate levels.


When listening to a classical composition that relies largely on instrumentals, the listener will notice the presence of smooth mids and clear trebles. A song like Childish Gambino's "Feel Like Summer," with contrasting tones, is a good example of the enchantment he can spread. Marshall Emberton only falls short in the bass department, particularly at higher volumes. However, this speaker best suits more subdued settings, such as a lounge room or a study. Marshall Emberton isn't designed for music purists. Its sound quality is impressive for its small size and low cost, although its soundstage instead of bass could need some improvement. Furthermore, there is no EQ-adjusting companion app.
content_list.subtitle: Putting In Place

content_list.content: Marshall Emberton II ($169.99) Bluetooth speaker is an improvement over its predecessor in terms of battery life and builds quality. Still, these improvements (combined with the speaker's updated aesthetic) are insufficient to warrant the price tag. The digital signal processing is too strong, and the app lacks a speakerphone feature, but the equalization settings are great. More powerful outdoor speakers are available at a similar price, such as the JBL Full control 5 ($179.95), which won the Editors' Choice award. Regarding portable Bluetooth speakers, Marshall Emberton may be the best option or a little pricey, depending on your needs. Let us elaborate: The Emberton is more affordable than its rivals at $149, but it is smaller and has less power. However, its small size might be an advantage over many bigger, bulkier ones. There may be a little loss of bass when turning up the volume.
